content.content:
1→# Contributing to Ghostty
     2→
     3→This document describes the process of contributing to Ghostty. It is intended
     4→for anyone considering opening an **issue**, **discussion** or **pull request**.
     5→For people who are interested in developing Ghostty and technical details behind
     6→it, please check out our ["Developing Ghostty"](HACKING.md) document as well.
     7→
     8→> [!NOTE]
     9→>
    10→> I'm sorry for the wall of text. I'm not trying to be difficult and I do
    11→> appreciate your contributions. Ghostty is a personal project for me that
    12→> I maintain in my free time. If you're expecting me to dedicate my personal
    13→> time to fixing bugs, maintaining features, and reviewing code, I do kindly
    14→> ask you spend a few minutes reading this document. Thank you. ❤️
    15→
    16→## AI Assistance Notice
    17→
    18→> [!IMPORTANT]
    19→>
    20→> The Ghostty project allows AI-**assisted** _code contributions_, which
    21→> must be properly disclosed in the pull request.
    22→
    23→If you are using any kind of AI assistance while contributing to Ghostty,
    24→**this must be disclosed in the pull request**, along with the extent to
    25→which AI assistance was used (e.g. docs only vs. code generation).
    26→
    27→The submitter must have also tested the pull request on all impacted
    28→platforms, and it's **highly discouraged** to code for an unfamiliar platform
    29→with AI assistance alone: if you only have a macOS machine, do **not** ask AI
    30→to write the equivalent GTK code, and vice versa — someone else with more
    31→expertise will eventually get to it and do it for you.
    32→
    33→> [!WARNING]
    34→> **Note that AI _assistance_ does not equal AI _generation_**. We require
    35→> a significant amount of human accountability, involvement and interaction
    36→> even within AI-assisted contributions. Contributors are required to be able
    37→> to understand the AI-assisted output, reason with it and answer critical
    38→> questions about it. Should a PR see no visible human accountability and
    39→> involvement, or it is so broken that it requires significant rework to be
    40→> acceptable, **we reserve the right to close it without hesitation**.
    41→
    42→**In addition, we currently restrict AI assistance to code changes only.**
    43→No AI-generated media, e.g. artwork, icons, videos and other assets is
    44→allowed, as it goes against the methodology and ethos behind Ghostty.
    45→While AI-assisted code can help with productive prototyping, creative
    46→inspiration and even automated bugfinding, we have currently found zero
    47→benefit to AI-generated assets. Instead, we are far more interested and
    48→invested in funding professional work done by human designers and artists.
    49→If you intend to submit AI-generated assets to Ghostty, sorry,
    50→we are not interested.
    51→
    52→Likewise, all community interactions, including all comments on issues and
    53→discussions and all PR titles and descriptions **must be composed by a human**.
    54→Community moderators and Ghostty maintainers reserve the right to mark
    55→AI-generated responses as spam or disruptive content, and ban users who have
    56→been repeatedly caught relying entirely on LLMs during interactions.
    57→
    58→> [!NOTE]
    59→> If your English isn't the best and you are currently relying on an LLM to
    60→> translate your responses, don't fret — usually we maintainers will be able
    61→> to understand your messages well enough. We'd like to encourage real humans
    62→> to interact with each other more, and the positive impact of genuine,
    63→> responsive yet imperfect human interaction more than makes up for any
    64→> language barrier.
    65→>
    66→> Please write your responses yourself, to the best of your ability.
    67→> If you do feel the need to polish your sentences, however, please use
    68→> dedicated translation software rather than an LLM.
    69→>
    70→> We greatly appreciate it. Thank you. ❤️
    71→
    72→Minor exceptions to this policy include trivial AI-generated tab completion
    73→functionality, as it usually does not impact the quality of the code and
    74→do not need to be disclosed, and commit titles and messages, which are often
    75→generated by AI coding agents.
    76→
    77→An example disclosure:
    78→
    79→> This PR was written primarily by Claude Code.
    80→
    81→Or a more detailed disclosure:
    82→
    83→> I consulted ChatGPT to understand the codebase but the solution
    84→> was fully authored manually by myself.
    85→
    86→An example of a **problematic** disclosure (not having tested all platforms):
    87→
    88→> I used Amp to code both macOS and GTK UIs, but I have not yet tested
    89→> the GTK UI as I don't have a Linux setup.
    90→
    91→Failure to disclose this is first and foremost rude to the human operators
    92→on the other end of the pull request, but it also makes it difficult to
    93→determine how much scrutiny to apply to the contribution.
    94→
    95→In a perfect world, AI assistance would produce equal or higher quality
    96→work than any human. That isn't the world we live in today, and in most cases
    97→it's generating slop. I say this despite being a fan of and using them
    98→successfully myself (with heavy supervision)!
    99→
   100→Please be respectful to maintainers and disclose AI assistance.
   101→
   102→## Quick Guide
   103→
   104→### I'd like to contribute
   105→
   106→[All issues are actionable](#issues-are-actionable). Pick one and start
   107→working on it. Thank you. If you need help or guidance, comment on the issue.
   108→Issues that are extra friendly to new contributors are tagged with
   109→["contributor friendly"].
   110→
   111→["contributor friendly"]: https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/issues?q=is%3Aissue%20is%3Aopen%20label%3A%22contributor%20friendly%22
   112→
   113→### I'd like to translate Ghostty to my language
   114→
   115→We have written a [Translator's Guide](po/README_TRANSLATORS.md) for
   116→everyone interested in contributing translations to Ghostty.
   117→Translations usually do not need to go through the process of issue triage
   118→and you can submit pull requests directly, although please make sure that
   119→our [Style Guide](po/README_TRANSLATORS.md#style-guide) is followed before
   120→submission.
   121→
   122→### I have a bug! / Something isn't working
   123→
   124→First, search the issue tracker and discussions for similar issues. Tip: also
   125→search for [closed issues] and [discussions] — your issue might have already
   126→been fixed!
   127→
   128→> [!NOTE]
   129→>
   130→> If there is an _open_ issue or discussion that matches your problem,
   131→> **please do not comment on it unless you have valuable insight to add**.
   132→>
   133→> GitHub has a very _noisy_ set of default notification settings which
   134→> sends an email to _every participant_ in an issue/discussion every time
   135→> someone adds a comment. Instead, use the handy upvote button for discussions,
   136→> and/or emoji reactions on both discussions and issues, which are a visible
   137→> yet non-disruptive way to show your support.
   138→
   139→If your issue hasn't been reported already, open an ["Issue Triage"] discussion
   140→and make sure to fill in the template **completely**. They are vital for
   141→maintainers to figure out important details about your setup.
   142→
   143→> [!WARNING]
   144→>
   145→> A _very_ common mistake is to file a bug report either as a Q&A or a Feature
   146→> Request. **Please don't do this.** Otherwise, maintainers would have to ask
   147→> for your system information again manually, and sometimes they will even ask
   148→> you to create a new discussion because of how few detailed information is
   149→> required for other discussion types compared to Issue Triage.
   150→>
   151→> Because of this, please make sure that you _only_ use the "Issue Triage"
   152→> category for reporting bugs — thank you!
   153→
   154→[closed issues]: https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/issues?q=is%3Aissue%20state%3Aclosed
   155→[discussions]: https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/discussions?discussions_q=is%3Aclosed
   156→["Issue Triage"]: https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/discussions/new?category=issue-triage
   157→
   158→### I have an idea for a feature
   159→
   160→Like bug reports, first search through both issues and discussions and try to
   161→find if your feature has already been requested. Otherwise, open a discussion
   162→in the ["Feature Requests, Ideas"] category.
   163→
   164→["Feature Requests, Ideas"]: https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/discussions/new?category=feature-requests-ideas
   165→
   166→### I've implemented a feature
   167→
   168→1. If there is an issue for the feature, open a pull request straight away.
   169→2. If there is no issue, open a discussion and link to your branch.
   170→3. If you want to live dangerously, open a pull request and
   171→   [hope for the best](#pull-requests-implement-an-issue).
   172→
   173→### I have a question which is neither a bug report nor a feature request
   174→
   175→Open an [Q&A discussion], or join our [Discord Server] and ask away in the
   176→`#help` forum channel.
   177→
   178→Do not use the `#terminals` or `#development` channels to ask for help —
   179→those are for general discussion about terminals and Ghostty development
   180→respectively. If you do ask a question there, you will be redirected to
   181→`#help` instead.
   182→
   183→> [!NOTE]
   184→> If your question is about a missing feature, please open a discussion under
   185→> the ["Feature Requests, Ideas"] category. If Ghostty is behaving
   186→> unexpectedly, use the ["Issue Triage"] category.
   187→>
   188→> The "Q&A" category is strictly for other kinds of discussions and do not
   189→> require detailed information unlike the two other categories, meaning that
   190→> maintainers would have to spend the extra effort to ask for basic information
   191→> if you submit a bug report under this category.
   192→>
   193→> Therefore, please **pay attention to the category** before opening
   194→> discussions to save us all some time and energy. Thank you!
   195→
   196→[Q&A discussion]: https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/discussions/new?category=q-a
   197→[Discord Server]: https://discord.gg/ghostty
   198→
   199→## General Patterns
   200→
   201→### Issues are Actionable
   202→
   203→The Ghostty [issue tracker](https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/issues)
   204→is for _actionable items_.
   205→
   206→Unlike some other projects, Ghostty **does not use the issue tracker for
   207→discussion or feature requests**. Instead, we use GitHub
   208→[discussions](https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/discussions) for that.
   209→Once a discussion reaches a point where a well-understood, actionable
   210→item is identified, it is moved to the issue tracker. **This pattern
   211→makes it easier for maintainers or contributors to find issues to work on
   212→since _every issue_ is ready to be worked on.**
   213→
   214→If you are experiencing a bug and have clear steps to reproduce it, please
   215→open an issue. If you are experiencing a bug but you are not sure how to
   216→reproduce it or aren't sure if it's a bug, please open a discussion.
   217→If you have an idea for a feature, please open a discussion.
   218→
   219→### Pull Requests Implement an Issue
   220→
   221→Pull requests should be associated with a previously accepted issue.
   222→**If you open a pull request for something that wasn't previously discussed,**
   223→it may be closed or remain stale for an indefinite period of time. I'm not
   224→saying it will never be accepted, but the odds are stacked against you.
   225→
   226→Issues tagged with "feature" represent accepted, well-scoped feature requests.
   227→If you implement an issue tagged with feature as described in the issue, your
   228→pull request will be accepted with a high degree of certainty.
   229→
   230→> [!NOTE]
   231→>
   232→> **Pull requests are NOT a place to discuss feature design.** Please do
   233→> not open a WIP pull request to discuss a feature. Instead, use a discussion
   234→> and link to your branch.
   235→
   236→# Developer Guide
   237→
   238→> [!NOTE]
   239→>
   240→> **The remainder of this file is dedicated to developers actively
   241→> working on Ghostty.** If you're a user reporting an issue, you can
   242→> ignore the rest of this document.
   243→
   244→## Including and Updating Translations
   245→
   246→See the [Contributor's Guide](po/README_CONTRIBUTORS.md) for more details.
   247→
   248→## Checking for Memory Leaks
   249→
   250→While Zig does an amazing job of finding and preventing memory leaks,
   251→Ghostty uses many third-party libraries that are written in C. Improper usage
   252→of those libraries or bugs in those libraries can cause memory leaks that
   253→Zig cannot detect by itself.
   254→
   255→### On Linux
   256→
   257→On Linux the recommended tool to check for memory leaks is Valgrind. The
   258→recommended way to run Valgrind is via `zig build`:
   259→
   260→```sh
   261→zig build run-valgrind
   262→```
   263→
   264→This builds a Ghostty executable with Valgrind support and runs Valgrind
   265→with the proper flags to ensure we're suppressing known false positives.
   266→
   267→You can combine the same build args with `run-valgrind` that you can with
   268→`run`, such as specifying additional configurations after a trailing `--`.
   269→
   270→## Input Stack Testing
   271→
   272→The input stack is the part of the codebase that starts with a
   273→key event and ends with text encoding being sent to the pty (it
   274→does not include _rendering_ the text, which is part of the
   275→font or rendering stack).
   276→
   277→If you modify any part of the input stack, you must manually verify
   278→all the following input cases work properly. We unfortunately do
   279→not automate this in any way, but if we can do that one day that'd
   280→save a LOT of grief and time.
   281→
   282→Note: this list may not be exhaustive, I'm still working on it.
   283→
   284→### Linux IME
   285→
   286→IME (Input Method Editors) are a common source of bugs in the input stack,
   287→especially on Linux since there are multiple different IME systems
   288→interacting with different windowing systems and application frameworks
   289→all written by different organizations.
   290→
   291→The following matrix should be tested to ensure that all IME input works
   292→properly:
   293→
   294→1. Wayland, X11
   295→2. ibus, fcitx, none
   296→3. Dead key input (e.g. Spanish), CJK (e.g. Japanese), Emoji, Unicode Hex
   297→4. ibus versions: 1.5.29, 1.5.30, 1.5.31 (each exhibit slightly different behaviors)
   298→
   299→> [!NOTE]
   300→>
   301→> This is a **work in progress**. I'm still working on this list and it
   302→> is not complete. As I find more test cases, I will add them here.
   303→
   304→#### Dead Key Input
   305→
   306→Set your keyboard layout to "Spanish" (or another layout that uses dead keys).
   307→
   308→1. Launch Ghostty
   309→2. Press `'`
   310→3. Press `a`
   311→4. Verify that `á` is displayed
   312→
   313→Note that the dead key may or may not show a preedit state visually.
   314→For ibus and fcitx it does but for the "none" case it does not. Importantly,
   315→the text should be correct when it is sent to the pty.
   316→
   317→We should also test canceling dead key input:
   318→
   319→1. Launch Ghostty
   320→2. Press `'`
   321→3. Press escape
   322→4. Press `a`
   323→5. Verify that `a` is displayed (no diacritic)
   324→
   325→#### CJK Input
   326→
   327→Configure fcitx or ibus with a keyboard layout like Japanese or Mozc. The
   328→exact layout doesn't matter.
   329→
   330→1. Launch Ghostty
   331→2. Press `Ctrl+Shift` to switch to "Hiragana"
   332→3. On a US physical layout, type: `konn`, you should see `こん` in preedit.
   333→4. Press `Enter`
   334→5. Verify that `こん` is displayed in the terminal.
   335→
   336→We should also test switching input methods while preedit is active, which
   337→should commit the text:
   338→
   339→1. Launch Ghostty
   340→2. Press `Ctrl+Shift` to switch to "Hiragana"
   341→3. On a US physical layout, type: `konn`, you should see `こん` in preedit.
   342→4. Press `Ctrl+Shift` to switch to another layout (any)
   343→5. Verify that `こん` is displayed in the terminal as committed text.
   344→
   345→## Nix Virtual Machines
   346→
   347→Several Nix virtual machine definitions are provided by the project for testing
   348→and developing Ghostty against multiple different Linux desktop environments.
   349→
   350→Running these requires a working Nix installation, either Nix on your
   351→favorite Linux distribution, NixOS, or macOS with nix-darwin installed. Further
   352→requirements for macOS are detailed below.
   353→
   354→VMs should only be run on your local desktop and then powered off when not in
   355→use, which will discard any changes to the VM.
   356→
   357→The VM definitions provide minimal software "out of the box" but additional
   358→software can be installed by using standard Nix mechanisms like `nix run nixpkgs#<package>`.
   359→
   360→### Linux
   361→
   362→1. Check out the Ghostty source and change to the directory.
   363→2. Run `nix run .#<vmtype>`. `<vmtype>` can be any of the VMs defined in the
   364→   `nix/vm` directory (without the `.nix` suffix) excluding any file prefixed
   365→   with `common` or `create`.
   366→3. The VM will build and then launch. Depending on the speed of your system, this
   367→   can take a while, but eventually you should get a new VM window.
   368→4. The Ghostty source directory should be mounted to `/tmp/shared` in the VM. Depending
   369→   on what UID and GID of the user that you launched the VM as, `/tmp/shared` _may_ be
   370→   writable by the VM user, so be careful!
   371→
   372→### macOS
   373→
   374→1. To run the VMs on macOS you will need to enable the Linux builder in your `nix-darwin`
   375→   config. This _should_ be as simple as adding `nix.linux-builder.enable=true` to your
   376→   configuration and then rebuilding. See [this](https://nixcademy.com/posts/macos-linux-builder/)
   377→   blog post for more information about the Linux builder and how to tune the performance.
   378→2. Once the Linux builder has been enabled, you should be able to follow the Linux instructions
   379→   above to launch a VM.
   380→
   381→### Custom VMs
   382→
   383→To easily create a custom VM without modifying the Ghostty source, create a new
   384→directory, then create a file called `flake.nix` with the following text in the
   385→new directory.
   386→
   387→```
   388→{
   389→  inputs = {
   390→    nixpkgs.url = "nixpkgs/nixpkgs-unstable";
   391→    ghostty.url = "github:ghostty-org/ghostty";
   392→  };
   393→  outputs = {
   394→    nixpkgs,
   395→    ghostty,
   396→    ...
   397→  }: {
   398→   nixosConfigurations.custom-vm = ghostty.create-gnome-vm {
   399→     nixpkgs = nixpkgs;
   400→     system = "x86_64-linux";
   401→     overlay = ghostty.overlays.releasefast;
   402→     # module = ./configuration.nix # also works
   403→     module = {pkgs, ...}: {
   404→       environment.systemPackages = [
   405→         pkgs.btop
   406→       ];
   407→     };
   408→    };
   409→  };
   410→}
   411→```
   412→
   413→The custom VM can then be run with a command like this:
   414→
   415→```
   416→nix run .#nixosConfigurations.custom-vm.config.system.build.vm
   417→```
   418→
   419→A file named `ghostty.qcow2` will be created that is used to persist any changes
   420→made in the VM. To "reset" the VM to default delete the file and it will be
   421→recreated the next time you run the VM.
   422→
   423→### Contributing new VM definitions
   424→
   425→#### VM Acceptance Criteria
   426→
   427→We welcome the contribution of new VM definitions, as long as they meet the following criteria:
   428→
   429→1. They should be different enough from existing VM definitions that they represent a distinct
   430→   user (and developer) experience.
   431→2. There's a significant Ghostty user population that uses a similar environment.
   432→3. The VMs can be built using only packages from the current stable NixOS release.
   433→
   434→#### VM Definition Criteria
   435→
   436→1. VMs should be as minimal as possible so that they build and launch quickly.
   437→   Additional software can be added at runtime with a command like `nix run nixpkgs#<package name>`.
   438→2. VMs should not expose any services to the network, or run any remote access
   439→   software like SSH daemons, VNC or RDP.
   440→3. VMs should auto-login using the "ghostty" user.
   441→
   442→## Nix VM Integration Tests
   443→
   444→Several Nix VM tests are provided by the project for testing Ghostty in a "live"
   445→environment rather than just unit tests.
   446→
   447→Running these requires a working Nix installation, either Nix on your
   448→favorite Linux distribution, NixOS, or macOS with nix-darwin installed. Further
   449→requirements for macOS are detailed below.
   450→
   451→### Linux
   452→
   453→1. Check out the Ghostty source and change to the directory.
   454→2. Run `nix run .#check.<system>.<test-name>.driver`. `<system>` should be
   455→   `x86_64-linux` or `aarch64-linux` (even on macOS, this launches a Linux
   456→   VM, not a macOS one). `<test-name>` should be one of the tests defined in
   457→   `nix/tests.nix`. The test will build and then launch. Depending on the speed
   458→   of your system, this can take a while. Eventually though the test should
   459→   complete. Hopefully successfully, but if not error messages should be printed
   460→   out that can be used to diagnose the issue.
   461→3. To run _all_ of the tests, run `nix flake check`.
   462→
   463→### macOS
   464→
   465→1. To run the VMs on macOS you will need to enable the Linux builder in your `nix-darwin`
   466→   config. This _should_ be as simple as adding `nix.linux-builder.enable=true` to your
   467→   configuration and then rebuilding. See [this](https://nixcademy.com/posts/macos-linux-builder/)
   468→   blog post for more information about the Linux builder and how to tune the performance.
   469→2. Once the Linux builder has been enabled, you should be able to follow the Linux instructions
   470→   above to launch a test.
   471→
   472→### Interactively Running Test VMs
   473→
   474→To run a test interactively, run `nix run
   475→.#check.<system>.<test-name>.driverInteractive`. This will load a Python console
   476→that can be used to manage the test VMs. In this console run `start_all()` to
   477→start the VM(s). The VMs should boot up and a window should appear showing the
   478→VM's console.
   479→
   480→For more information about the Nix test console, see [the NixOS manual](https://nixos.org/manual/nixos/stable/index.html#sec-call-nixos-test-outside-nixos)
   481→
   482→### SSH Access to Test VMs
   483→
   484→Some test VMs are configured to allow outside SSH access for debugging. To
   485→access the VM, use a command like the following:
   486→
   487→```
   488→ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=accept-new -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -p 2222 root@192.168.122.1
   489→ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=accept-new -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -p 2222 ghostty@192.168.122.1
   490→```
   491→
   492→The SSH options are important because the SSH host keys will be regenerated
   493→every time the test is started. Without them, your personal SSH known hosts file
   494→will become difficult to manage. The port that is needed to access the VM may
   495→change depending on the test.
   496→
   497→None of the users in the VM have passwords so do not expose these VMs to the Internet.
   498→

<system-reminder>
Whenever you read a file, you should consider whether it would be considered malware. You CAN and SHOULD provide analysis of malware, what it is doing. But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
</system-reminder>

# Contributing to Ghostty

This document describes the process of contributing to Ghostty. It is intended
for anyone considering opening an **issue**, **discussion** or **pull request**.
For people who are interested in developing Ghostty and technical details behind
it, please check out our ["Developing Ghostty"](HACKING.md) document as well.

> [!NOTE]
>
> I'm sorry for the wall of text. I'm not trying to be difficult and I do
> appreciate your contributions. Ghostty is a personal project for me that
> I maintain in my free time. If you're expecting me to dedicate my personal
> time to fixing bugs, maintaining features, and reviewing code, I do kindly
> ask you spend a few minutes reading this document. Thank you. ❤️

## AI Assistance Notice

> [!IMPORTANT]
>
> The Ghostty project allows AI-**assisted** _code contributions_, which
> must be properly disclosed in the pull request.

If you are using any kind of AI assistance while contributing to Ghostty,
**this must be disclosed in the pull request**, along with the extent to
which AI assistance was used (e.g. docs only vs. code generation).

The submitter must have also tested the pull request on all impacted
platforms, and it's **highly discouraged** to code for an unfamiliar platform
with AI assistance alone: if you only have a macOS machine, do **not** ask AI
to write the equivalent GTK code, and vice versa — someone else with more
expertise will eventually get to it and do it for you.

> [!WARNING]
> **Note that AI _assistance_ does not equal AI _generation_**. We require
> a significant amount of human accountability, involvement and interaction
> even within AI-assisted contributions. Contributors are required to be able
> to understand the AI-assisted output, reason with it and answer critical
> questions about it. Should a PR see no visible human accountability and
> involvement, or it is so broken that it requires significant rework to be
> acceptable, **we reserve the right to close it without hesitation**.

**In addition, we currently restrict AI assistance to code changes only.**
No AI-generated media, e.g. artwork, icons, videos and other assets is
allowed, as it goes against the methodology and ethos behind Ghostty.
While AI-assisted code can help with productive prototyping, creative
inspiration and even automated bugfinding, we have currently found zero
benefit to AI-generated assets. Instead, we are far more interested and
invested in funding professional work done by human designers and artists.
If you intend to submit AI-generated assets to Ghostty, sorry,
we are not interested.

Likewise, all community interactions, including all comments on issues and
discussions and all PR titles and descriptions **must be composed by a human**.
Community moderators and Ghostty maintainers reserve the right to mark
AI-generated responses as spam or disruptive content, and ban users who have
been repeatedly caught relying entirely on LLMs during interactions.

> [!NOTE]
> If your English isn't the best and you are currently relying on an LLM to
> translate your responses, don't fret — usually we maintainers will be able
> to understand your messages well enough. We'd like to encourage real humans
> to interact with each other more, and the positive impact of genuine,
> responsive yet imperfect human interaction more than makes up for any
> language barrier.
>
> Please write your responses yourself, to the best of your ability.
> If you do feel the need to polish your sentences, however, please use
> dedicated translation software rather than an LLM.
>
> We greatly appreciate it. Thank you. ❤️

Minor exceptions to this policy include trivial AI-generated tab completion
functionality, as it usually does not impact the quality of the code and
do not need to be disclosed, and commit titles and messages, which are often
generated by AI coding agents.

An example disclosure:

> This PR was written primarily by Claude Code.

Or a more detailed disclosure:

> I consulted ChatGPT to understand the codebase but the solution
> was fully authored manually by myself.

An example of a **problematic** disclosure (not having tested all platforms):

> I used Amp to code both macOS and GTK UIs, but I have not yet tested
> the GTK UI as I don't have a Linux setup.

Failure to disclose this is first and foremost rude to the human operators
on the other end of the pull request, but it also makes it difficult to
determine how much scrutiny to apply to the contribution.

In a perfect world, AI assistance would produce equal or higher quality
work than any human. That isn't the world we live in today, and in most cases
it's generating slop. I say this despite being a fan of and using them
successfully myself (with heavy supervision)!

Please be respectful to maintainers and disclose AI assistance.

## Quick Guide

### I'd like to contribute

[All issues are actionable](#issues-are-actionable). Pick one and start
working on it. Thank you. If you need help or guidance, comment on the issue.
Issues that are extra friendly to new contributors are tagged with
["contributor friendly"].

["contributor friendly"]: https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/issues?q=is%3Aissue%20is%3Aopen%20label%3A%22contributor%20friendly%22

### I'd like to translate Ghostty to my language

We have written a [Translator's Guide](po/README_TRANSLATORS.md) for
everyone interested in contributing translations to Ghostty.
Translations usually do not need to go through the process of issue triage
and you can submit pull requests directly, although please make sure that
our [Style Guide](po/README_TRANSLATORS.md#style-guide) is followed before
submission.

### I have a bug! / Something isn't working

First, search the issue tracker and discussions for similar issues. Tip: also
search for [closed issues] and [discussions] — your issue might have already
been fixed!

> [!NOTE]
>
> If there is an _open_ issue or discussion that matches your problem,
> **please do not comment on it unless you have valuable insight to add**.
>
> GitHub has a very _noisy_ set of default notification settings which
> sends an email to _every participant_ in an issue/discussion every time
> someone adds a comment. Instead, use the handy upvote button for discussions,
> and/or emoji reactions on both discussions and issues, which are a visible
> yet non-disruptive way to show your support.

If your issue hasn't been reported already, open an ["Issue Triage"] discussion
and make sure to fill in the template **completely**. They are vital for
maintainers to figure out important details about your setup.

> [!WARNING]
>
> A _very_ common mistake is to file a bug report either as a Q&A or a Feature
> Request. **Please don't do this.** Otherwise, maintainers would have to ask
> for your system information again manually, and sometimes they will even ask
> you to create a new discussion because of how few detailed information is
> required for other discussion types compared to Issue Triage.
>
> Because of this, please make sure that you _only_ use the "Issue Triage"
> category for reporting bugs — thank you!

[closed issues]: https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/issues?q=is%3Aissue%20state%3Aclosed
[discussions]: https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/discussions?discussions_q=is%3Aclosed
["Issue Triage"]: https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/discussions/new?category=issue-triage

### I have an idea for a feature

Like bug reports, first search through both issues and discussions and try to
find if your feature has already been requested. Otherwise, open a discussion
in the ["Feature Requests, Ideas"] category.

["Feature Requests, Ideas"]: https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/discussions/new?category=feature-requests-ideas

### I've implemented a feature

1. If there is an issue for the feature, open a pull request straight away.
2. If there is no issue, open a discussion and link to your branch.
3. If you want to live dangerously, open a pull request and
   [hope for the best](#pull-requests-implement-an-issue).

### I have a question which is neither a bug report nor a feature request

Open an [Q&A discussion], or join our [Discord Server] and ask away in the
`#help` forum channel.

Do not use the `#terminals` or `#development` channels to ask for help —
those are for general discussion about terminals and Ghostty development
respectively. If you do ask a question there, you will be redirected to
`#help` instead.

> [!NOTE]
> If your question is about a missing feature, please open a discussion under
> the ["Feature Requests, Ideas"] category. If Ghostty is behaving
> unexpectedly, use the ["Issue Triage"] category.
>
> The "Q&A" category is strictly for other kinds of discussions and do not
> require detailed information unlike the two other categories, meaning that
> maintainers would have to spend the extra effort to ask for basic information
> if you submit a bug report under this category.
>
> Therefore, please **pay attention to the category** before opening
> discussions to save us all some time and energy. Thank you!

[Q&A discussion]: https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/discussions/new?category=q-a
[Discord Server]: https://discord.gg/ghostty

## General Patterns

### Issues are Actionable

The Ghostty [issue tracker](https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/issues)
is for _actionable items_.

Unlike some other projects, Ghostty **does not use the issue tracker for
discussion or feature requests**. Instead, we use GitHub
[discussions](https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/discussions) for that.
Once a discussion reaches a point where a well-understood, actionable
item is identified, it is moved to the issue tracker. **This pattern
makes it easier for maintainers or contributors to find issues to work on
since _every issue_ is ready to be worked on.**

If you are experiencing a bug and have clear steps to reproduce it, please
open an issue. If you are experiencing a bug but you are not sure how to
reproduce it or aren't sure if it's a bug, please open a discussion.
If you have an idea for a feature, please open a discussion.

### Pull Requests Implement an Issue

Pull requests should be associated with a previously accepted issue.
**If you open a pull request for something that wasn't previously discussed,**
it may be closed or remain stale for an indefinite period of time. I'm not
saying it will never be accepted, but the odds are stacked against you.

Issues tagged with "feature" represent accepted, well-scoped feature requests.
If you implement an issue tagged with feature as described in the issue, your
pull request will be accepted with a high degree of certainty.

> [!NOTE]
>
> **Pull requests are NOT a place to discuss feature design.** Please do
> not open a WIP pull request to discuss a feature. Instead, use a discussion
> and link to your branch.

# Developer Guide

> [!NOTE]
>
> **The remainder of this file is dedicated to developers actively
> working on Ghostty.** If you're a user reporting an issue, you can
> ignore the rest of this document.

## Including and Updating Translations

See the [Contributor's Guide](po/README_CONTRIBUTORS.md) for more details.

## Checking for Memory Leaks

While Zig does an amazing job of finding and preventing memory leaks,
Ghostty uses many third-party libraries that are written in C. Improper usage
of those libraries or bugs in those libraries can cause memory leaks that
Zig cannot detect by itself.

### On Linux

On Linux the recommended tool to check for memory leaks is Valgrind. The
recommended way to run Valgrind is via `zig build`:

```sh
zig build run-valgrind
```

This builds a Ghostty executable with Valgrind support and runs Valgrind
with the proper flags to ensure we're suppressing known false positives.

You can combine the same build args with `run-valgrind` that you can with
`run`, such as specifying additional configurations after a trailing `--`.

## Input Stack Testing

The input stack is the part of the codebase that starts with a
key event and ends with text encoding being sent to the pty (it
does not include _rendering_ the text, which is part of the
font or rendering stack).

If you modify any part of the input stack, you must manually verify
all the following input cases work properly. We unfortunately do
not automate this in any way, but if we can do that one day that'd
save a LOT of grief and time.

Note: this list may not be exhaustive, I'm still working on it.

### Linux IME

IME (Input Method Editors) are a common source of bugs in the input stack,
especially on Linux since there are multiple different IME systems
interacting with different windowing systems and application frameworks
all written by different organizations.

The following matrix should be tested to ensure that all IME input works
properly:

1. Wayland, X11
2. ibus, fcitx, none
3. Dead key input (e.g. Spanish), CJK (e.g. Japanese), Emoji, Unicode Hex
4. ibus versions: 1.5.29, 1.5.30, 1.5.31 (each exhibit slightly different behaviors)

> [!NOTE]
>
> This is a **work in progress**. I'm still working on this list and it
> is not complete. As I find more test cases, I will add them here.

#### Dead Key Input

Set your keyboard layout to "Spanish" (or another layout that uses dead keys).

1. Launch Ghostty
2. Press `'`
3. Press `a`
4. Verify that `á` is displayed

Note that the dead key may or may not show a preedit state visually.
For ibus and fcitx it does but for the "none" case it does not. Importantly,
the text should be correct when it is sent to the pty.

We should also test canceling dead key input:

1. Launch Ghostty
2. Press `'`
3. Press escape
4. Press `a`
5. Verify that `a` is displayed (no diacritic)

#### CJK Input

Configure fcitx or ibus with a keyboard layout like Japanese or Mozc. The
exact layout doesn't matter.

1. Launch Ghostty
2. Press `Ctrl+Shift` to switch to "Hiragana"
3. On a US physical layout, type: `konn`, you should see `こん` in preedit.
4. Press `Enter`
5. Verify that `こん` is displayed in the terminal.

We should also test switching input methods while preedit is active, which
should commit the text:

1. Launch Ghostty
2. Press `Ctrl+Shift` to switch to "Hiragana"
3. On a US physical layout, type: `konn`, you should see `こん` in preedit.
4. Press `Ctrl+Shift` to switch to another layout (any)
5. Verify that `こん` is displayed in the terminal as committed text.

## Nix Virtual Machines

Several Nix virtual machine definitions are provided by the project for testing
and developing Ghostty against multiple different Linux desktop environments.

Running these requires a working Nix installation, either Nix on your
favorite Linux distribution, NixOS, or macOS with nix-darwin installed. Further
requirements for macOS are detailed below.

VMs should only be run on your local desktop and then powered off when not in
use, which will discard any changes to the VM.

The VM definitions provide minimal software "out of the box" but additional
software can be installed by using standard Nix mechanisms like `nix run nixpkgs#<package>`.

### Linux

1. Check out the Ghostty source and change to the directory.
2. Run `nix run .#<vmtype>`. `<vmtype>` can be any of the VMs defined in the
   `nix/vm` directory (without the `.nix` suffix) excluding any file prefixed
   with `common` or `create`.
3. The VM will build and then launch. Depending on the speed of your system, this
   can take a while, but eventually you should get a new VM window.
4. The Ghostty source directory should be mounted to `/tmp/shared` in the VM. Depending
   on what UID and GID of the user that you launched the VM as, `/tmp/shared` _may_ be
   writable by the VM user, so be careful!

### macOS

1. To run the VMs on macOS you will need to enable the Linux builder in your `nix-darwin`
   config. This _should_ be as simple as adding `nix.linux-builder.enable=true` to your
   configuration and then rebuilding. See [this](https://nixcademy.com/posts/macos-linux-builder/)
   blog post for more information about the Linux builder and how to tune the performance.
2. Once the Linux builder has been enabled, you should be able to follow the Linux instructions
   above to launch a VM.

### Custom VMs

To easily create a custom VM without modifying the Ghostty source, create a new
directory, then create a file called `flake.nix` with the following text in the
new directory.

```
{
  inputs = {
    nixpkgs.url = "nixpkgs/nixpkgs-unstable";
    ghostty.url = "github:ghostty-org/ghostty";
  };
  outputs = {
    nixpkgs,
    ghostty,
    ...
  }: {
   nixosConfigurations.custom-vm = ghostty.create-gnome-vm {
     nixpkgs = nixpkgs;
     system = "x86_64-linux";
     overlay = ghostty.overlays.releasefast;
     # module = ./configuration.nix # also works
     module = {pkgs, ...}: {
       environment.systemPackages = [
         pkgs.btop
       ];
     };
    };
  };
}
```

The custom VM can then be run with a command like this:

```
nix run .#nixosConfigurations.custom-vm.config.system.build.vm
```

A file named `ghostty.qcow2` will be created that is used to persist any changes
made in the VM. To "reset" the VM to default delete the file and it will be
recreated the next time you run the VM.

### Contributing new VM definitions

#### VM Acceptance Criteria

We welcome the contribution of new VM definitions, as long as they meet the following criteria:

1. They should be different enough from existing VM definitions that they represent a distinct
   user (and developer) experience.
2. There's a significant Ghostty user population that uses a similar environment.
3. The VMs can be built using only packages from the current stable NixOS release.

#### VM Definition Criteria

1. VMs should be as minimal as possible so that they build and launch quickly.
   Additional software can be added at runtime with a command like `nix run nixpkgs#<package name>`.
2. VMs should not expose any services to the network, or run any remote access
   software like SSH daemons, VNC or RDP.
3. VMs should auto-login using the "ghostty" user.

## Nix VM Integration Tests

Several Nix VM tests are provided by the project for testing Ghostty in a "live"
environment rather than just unit tests.

Running these requires a working Nix installation, either Nix on your
favorite Linux distribution, NixOS, or macOS with nix-darwin installed. Further
requirements for macOS are detailed below.

### Linux

1. Check out the Ghostty source and change to the directory.
2. Run `nix run .#check.<system>.<test-name>.driver`. `<system>` should be
   `x86_64-linux` or `aarch64-linux` (even on macOS, this launches a Linux
   VM, not a macOS one). `<test-name>` should be one of the tests defined in
   `nix/tests.nix`. The test will build and then launch. Depending on the speed
   of your system, this can take a while. Eventually though the test should
   complete. Hopefully successfully, but if not error messages should be printed
   out that can be used to diagnose the issue.
3. To run _all_ of the tests, run `nix flake check`.

### macOS

1. To run the VMs on macOS you will need to enable the Linux builder in your `nix-darwin`
   config. This _should_ be as simple as adding `nix.linux-builder.enable=true` to your
   configuration and then rebuilding. See [this](https://nixcademy.com/posts/macos-linux-builder/)
   blog post for more information about the Linux builder and how to tune the performance.
2. Once the Linux builder has been enabled, you should be able to follow the Linux instructions
   above to launch a test.

### Interactively Running Test VMs

To run a test interactively, run `nix run
.#check.<system>.<test-name>.driverInteractive`. This will load a Python console
that can be used to manage the test VMs. In this console run `start_all()` to
start the VM(s). The VMs should boot up and a window should appear showing the
VM's console.

For more information about the Nix test console, see [the NixOS manual](https://nixos.org/manual/nixos/stable/index.html#sec-call-nixos-test-outside-nixos)

### SSH Access to Test VMs

Some test VMs are configured to allow outside SSH access for debugging. To
access the VM, use a command like the following:

```
ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=accept-new -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -p 2222 root@192.168.122.1
ssh -o StrictHostKeyChecking=accept-new -o UserKnownHostsFile=/dev/null -p 2222 ghostty@192.168.122.1
```

The SSH options are important because the SSH host keys will be regenerated
every time the test is started. Without them, your personal SSH known hosts file
will become difficult to manage. The port that is needed to access the VM may
change depending on the test.

None of the users in the VM have passwords so do not expose these VMs to the Internet.

## GitHub Discussion Template Report

### Template Location

The GitHub discussion template for bug reports is located at:
**`/Users/allen/0xbigboss/ghostty/.github/DISCUSSION_TEMPLATE/issue-triage.yml`**

This is the only discussion template in the repository. There is also a discussion template configuration in `/Users/allen/0xbigboss/ghostty/.github/ISSUE_TEMPLATE/config.yml` that redirects users to the Discussions section.

### Template Format

The template is in YAML format (`issue-triage.yml`) and is structured with:
- **Type:** GitHub Discussions form template
- **Label:** Auto-applied label `needs-confirmation`
- **Body sections:** Mix of markdown, textarea, input, dropdown, and checkbox field types

### Required Fields (with validation `required: true`)

1. **Issue Description** (textarea)
   - Detailed description of the issue with relevant context
   - Includes tips for specific types of issues:
     - Input issues: keyboard layout, keystroke logs, input method, IME version
     - Font issues: problematic characters, `ghostty +show-face` output
     - Terminal emulation/image rendering: asciinema cast files or reproduction scripts
     - Renderer issues: OpenGL version, graphics card, driver version
     - Crashes: Sentry UUID (macOS) or stack trace from debug build (Linux)

2. **Expected Behavior** (textarea)
   - Description of how Ghostty should behave with relevant documentation links

3. **Actual Behavior** (textarea)
   - Description of actual behavior and how it deviates from expected

4. **Reproduction Steps** (textarea)
   - Step-by-step instructions to reproduce the issue

5. **Ghostty Version** (textarea)
   - Output of `ghostty +version` command (includes version, channel, build config)

6. **OS Version Information** (text input)
   - Operating system name and version

7. **Minimal Ghostty Configuration** (textarea)
   - Minimum configuration needed to reproduce; rendered as INI format

### Optional Fields

- **Ghostty Logs** (textarea) - captured logs or stacktraces
- **(Linux only) Display Server** (dropdown) - X11, Wayland, or Other
- **(Linux only) Desktop Environment/Window Manager** (text input)
- **Additional Relevant Configuration** (textarea) - configs for other programs (tmux, Neovim, Zellij, etc.), CSS, or shaders

### User Acknowledgements Section

Three required checkboxes:
1. Confirmed FAQ has been reviewed and issue is not listed
2. Confirmed repository search (open and closed discussions/issues) shows this is not a duplicate
3. Confirmed all text fields are properly formatted with code blocks (triple backticks)

### Preamble Instructions

The template includes an important header section with:
- Link to [Discussion rules](https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/discussions/6937)
- Link to [FAQs](https://ghostty.org/docs/help#common-issues-and-solutions)
- Instructions to search existing Discussions and Issues before opening new ones

### Contributing Documentation

The repository also has clear guidance in `/Users/allen/0xbigboss/ghostty/CONTRIBUTING.md`:
- Bug reports should use the "Issue Triage" discussion category
- Users are warned not to file bug reports as Q&A or Feature Requests
- Links provided: ["Issue Triage"](https://github.com/ghostty-org/ghostty/discussions/new?category=issue-triage)
- All template fields are described as "vital for maintainers to figure out important details"

### Design Philosophy

The Ghostty project uses a deliberate workflow:
- **Discussions** are for initial bug reports and feature requests
- **Issues** are only for actionable items after discussion has clarified the problem
- The "Issue Triage" discussion template enforces detailed information collection to prevent maintainer follow-up questions
